sentence.text: Case 3 is a male infant born at 40 weeks' gestation to a healthy 32-year-old gravida 4, para 1–2 mother, with a birth weight of 7 lb. (3182 gm).
The mother reported smoking 10 cigarettes per day but did not use alcohol, other drugs, or medications during the pregnancy.
A second-trimester ultrasound examination showed normal head growth, but all 4 limbs were short for gestational age.
No other abnormalities were identified.
Delivery was induced and precipitous.
Apgar scores were 9 and 9 at 1 and 5 min, respectively.
Immediately following delivery, deficient calcification of the calvarium was noted, but the infant was clinically stable.
Screening test results for levels of alkaline phosphatase, T4, and TSH were normal.
Shortly after discharge from the hospital (at 2 days of age), the infant became fussy and inconsolable and had decreased feeding.
Cranial imaging revealed multiple small areas of intraparenchymal hemorrhage.
Following admission to the hospital, his head shape was noted to change with positioning due to lack of calvarial ossification.
In addition, he developed increased effort of breathing, leading to the diagnosis of glossoptosis and severe tracheomalacia.
He required tracheostomy and bilevel positive airway pressure (BIPAP) to maintain normal oxygenation.
A physical examination identified a flat nasal bridge, epicanthic folds, hypertelorism, down-slanting palpebral fissures, and micrognathia.
The skull was soft with very large fontanels, and all of the sutures were very widely spaced, giving the impression of a nearly absent calvarium.
He was fitted with a helmet for protection and maintenance of a more normal head shape.
A 3D CT scan at 40 days of age demonstrated brachycephaly with incomplete ossification of the parietal, occipital, and frontal bones and multiple Wormian bones in the parietal regions (Fig. 1).
A chest radiograph revealed absent clavicles and thin ribs.
There was delayed ossification of the pubic symphysis.
At 12 months he had brachycephaly and a single large fontanel that measured 23 × 9 cm in greatest diameter, narrowing to 3 cm at the sagittal suture.
He continues to require BIPAP for tracheomalacia and has delayed gross motor skills.
He is age-appropriate for fine motor, cognitive, and social skills
